question: What is CRAO in the context of the eye?
ideal_answer: central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is an ophthalmological emergency, the retinal analog of a stroke.

Central retinal-artery obstruction (CRAO) is a devastating complication after retrobulbar anesthesia, a procedure which was previously recommended routinely to immobilize the eye and reduce discomfort during laser surgery.

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a rare complication of ICAD, secondary either to haemodynamic compromise, with ocular hypoperfusion and reverse flow within the ophthalmic artery, or to thromboembolic events, in rarer cases.
Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is an uncommon eye disorder, but one that typically produces severe and irreversible vision loss in the affected eye.
Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a medical emergency that, if not treated, may result in irreversible loss of vision.
